articles.headline: A.I.G. to Get Additional $37.8 Billion
articles.snippet: The aid comes in addition to the $85 billion line of credit the Fed gave the insurer last month.
articles.abstract: The aid comes in addition to the $85 billion line of credit the Fed gave the insurer last month.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve Board said Wednesday that it would provide up to $37.8 billion to the embattled insurer the American International Group to help it deal with a rapidly dwindling supply of cash.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: The Perfect Charger (Almost)
articles.snippet: The WildCharge mat replaces all those black power bricks you’ve been using to recharge your mobile doodads.
articles.abstract: The WildCharge mat replaces all those black power bricks you’ve been using to recharge your mobile doodads.
articles.lead_paragraph: Would you still want the power to fly, if you were required to put on a 117-piece set of chain mail before each flight? Would you still value instant teleportation, if you had to fill out a 72-page form before each jaunt? Would you still want control over the universe, if you had to power it by pedaling an exercise bike 14 hours a day?

articles.headline: U.S. Study Is Said to Warn of Crisis in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: A draft report by American intelligence agencies found that Afghanistan is in a “downward spiral.”
articles.abstract: A draft report by American intelligence agencies found that Afghanistan is in a “downward spiral.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A draft report by American intelligence agencies concludes that Afghanistan is in a “downward spiral” and casts serious doubt on the ability of the Afghan government to stem the rise in the Taliban’s influence there, according to American officials familiar with the document.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: States’ Actions to Block Voters Appear Illegal
articles.snippet: Tens of thousands of voters in at least six swing states have been removed from rolls or blocked from registering.
articles.abstract: Tens of thousands of voters in at least six swing states have been removed from rolls or blocked from registering.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of eligible voters in at least six swing states have been removed from the rolls or have been blocked from registering in ways that appear to violate federal law, according to a review of state records and Social Security data by The New York Times.

articles.headline: Switching to Cash May Feel Safe, but Risks Remain
articles.snippet: Fleeing the stock market for the comfort of safe and insured, investors with a time horizon beyond a few years may be doing real damage to their long-term finances.
articles.abstract: Fleeing the stock market for the comfort of safe and insured, investors with a time horizon beyond a few years may be doing real damage to their long-term finances.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s a question we’ve all asked in our darker moments of late: Why not just put all of our investments in cash, 100 percent, just for a little while, until things calm down?

articles.headline: G.O.P. Facing Tougher Battle for Congress
articles.snippet: The economic turmoil is threatening to topple Republican candidates, putting more seats within Democratic reach.
articles.abstract: The economic turmoil is threatening to topple Republican candidates, putting more seats within Democratic reach.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The economic upheaval is threatening to topple Republican Congressional candidates, putting more Senate and House seats within Democratic reach less than a month before the elections, lawmakers and campaign strategists say.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Bailout Role Elevates U.S. Official
articles.snippet: Neel T. Kashkari, 35, a former Goldman Sachs investment banker, was tapped by Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. to oversee the $700 billion bailout effort.
articles.abstract: Neel T. Kashkari, 35, a former Goldman Sachs investment banker, was tapped by Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. to oversee the $700 billion bailout effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For months, as Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. traveled to Capitol Hill to testify about the unfolding financial crisis, he has been shadowed by a man with a shaved head and intense eyes who many assumed was a Secret Service agent.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Ben White

articles.headline: Meltdown of Iceland’s Financial System Quickens
articles.snippet: The country was on the verge of going bankrupt as the government shut down the stock market and seized control of its last major independent bank.
articles.abstract: The country was on the verge of going bankrupt as the government shut down the stock market and seized control of its last major independent bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — People go bankrupt all the time. Companies do, too. But countries?

articles.headline: Taking Hard New Look at a Greenspan Legacy
articles.snippet: Derivatives have long had a great supporter in the former Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan.
articles.abstract: Derivatives have long had a great supporter in the former Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Not only have individual financial institutions become less vulnerable to shocks from underlying risk factors, but also the financial system as a whole has become more resilient.” — Alan Greenspan in 2004

articles.headline: Panicky Sellers Darken Afternoon on Wall Street
articles.snippet: A late-day decline again pushed the markets down sharply, with the Dow falling more than 600 points a year to the day after hitting its record high.
articles.abstract: A late-day decline again pushed the markets down sharply, with the Dow falling more than 600 points a year to the day after hitting its record high.
articles.lead_paragraph: Until 3 p.m. on Thursday, it seemed as if the stock market might escape another dark day.
